                                US Official News

                          September 18, 2013 Wednesday

Pesticide Emergency Exemptions; Agency Decisions and State and Federal Agency
Crisis Declarations

LENGTH: 1072  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Federal Register has issued the following notice:


Action

Notice.
Summary

EPA has granted emergency exemptions under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide,
and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) for use of pesticides as listed in this notice. The
exemptions were granted during the period October 1, 2012 through March 31, 2013
to control unforeseen pest outbreaks.

SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION: Back to Top
I. General Information Back to Top
A. Does this action apply to me?

You may be potentially affected by this action if you are an agricultural
producer, food manufacturer, or pesticide manufacturer. The following list of
North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) codes is not intended to
be exhaustive, but rather provides a guide to help readers determine whether
this document applies to them.

Potentially affected entities may include:

Crop production (NAICS code 111).
    Animal production (NAICS code 112).
    Food manufacturing (NAICS code 311).
    Pesticide manufacturing (NAICS code 32532).

B. How can I get copies of this document and other related information?

The docket for this action, identified by docket identification (ID) number
EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0069, is available at http://www.regulations.gov or at the
Office of Pesticide Programs Regulatory Public Docket (OPP Docket) in the
Environmental Protection Agency Docket Center (EPA/DC), EPA West Bldg., Rm.
3334, 1301 Constitution Ave. NW., Washington, DC 20460-0001. The Public Reading
Room is open from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding legal
holidays. The telephone number for the Public Reading Room is (202) 566-1744,
and the telephone number for the OPP Docket is (703) 305-5805. Please review the
visitor instructions and additional information about the docket available at
http://www.epa.gov/dockets.
II. Background Back to Top

EPA has granted emergency exemptions to the following State and Federal
agencies. The emergency exemptions may take the following form: Crisis, public
health, quarantine, or specific.

Under FIFRA section 18, EPA can authorize the use of a pesticide when emergency
conditions exist. Authorizations (commonly called emergency exemptions) are
granted to State and Federal agencies and are of four types:

1. A "specific exemption" authorizes use of a pesticide against specific pests
on limited acreage in a particular State. Most emergency exemptions are specific
exemptions.

2. "Quarantine" and "public health" exemptions are emergency exemptions issued
for quarantine or public health purposes. These are rarely requested.

3. A "crisis exemption" is initiated by a State or Federal agency (and is
confirmed by EPA) when there is insufficient time to request and obtain EPA
permission for use of a pesticide in an emergency.

EPA may deny an emergency exemption: If the State or Federal agency cannot
demonstrate that an emergency exists, if the use poses unacceptable risks to the
environment, or if EPA cannot reach a conclusion that the proposed pesticide use
is likely to result in "a reasonable certainty of no harm" to human health,
including exposure of residues of the pesticide to infants and children.

If the emergency use of the pesticide on a food or feed commodity would result
in pesticide chemical residues, EPA establishes a time-limited tolerance meeting
the "reasonable certainty of no harm standard" of the Federal Food, Drug, and
Cosmetic Act (FFDCA).

In this document: EPA identifies the State or Federal agency granted the
exemption, the type of exemption, the pesticide authorized and the pests, the
crop or use for which authorized, and the duration of the exemption. EPA also
gives the Federal Register citation for the time-limited tolerance, if any.
III. Emergency Exemptions Back to Top
A. U.S. States and Territories
Arkansas
State Plant Board

Specific exemption: EPA authorized the use of amitraz in beehives to control
varroa mite; December 10, 2012 to December 10, 2013.

Specific exemption: EPA authorized the use of potassium salt of hop beta acids
in beehives to control varroa mite on December 10, 2012; Effective

                               2 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                              June 24, 2011 Friday

Agricultural Cabinet to work for farmers' welfare

LENGTH: 998  words

DATELINE: India


India, June 24 -- To work in an integrated manner on matters relating to
agriculture, the Madhya Pradesh Government has introduced a separate Agriculture
Cabinet. This has spread a message that the State Government is sensitive
towards the farming community. After this, Madhya Pradesh has become the second
State in the country to have an exclusive "agriculture budget" in addition to
the general budget, which is presented annually in the State Assembly.

Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has been stressing on the welfare of
farmers and expressed his commitment towards making the farming as a profitable
business.

The only other State in the country to have such a budget is Karnataka, which
presented the first such budget in February this year. This step was taken in
view of the record production of wheat in recent times and also it has a large
agrarian population. The agriculture budget will focus on all the branches
related to farmland as horticulture, animal husbandry, fisheries, panchayats and
forestry. The intention of such a budget is to focus on development schemes
related to irrigation, power supply for farming and supply of fertilisers and
other goods to the farmers. The budget will be prepared in consultation with all
the stakeholders involved in agriculture.

The decision to form a separate Agriculture Cabinet was taken in the Cabinet
meeting on May 23.

It is believed that the Chief Minister was dissatisfied with the working of the
Agriculture Department, following which such a decision was taken.

The first meeting of the Agriculture Cabinet was held at Jabalpur Agriculture
University on June 18, in which several recommendations were made, that would be
implemented in the coming days.

To strengthen the agriculture sector, it has also been decided to observe a
"Krishi Mahotsava" throughout the State from September 25 to October 12.

The Agriculture Cabinet is be chaired by the Chief Minister and will comprise
Ministers for Agriculture, Horticulture, Animal Husbandry and Dairy, Fisheries,
Cooperative, Water Resources, Narmada Valley Development, Energy, Panchayat and
Rural Development, SC-ST Welfare and Forest. The committee will fix short-term
and long-term strategies for agriculture-related sectors and will also consult
experts for it.

A concept called 'Agriculture Budget' will be evolved, by tabling the budgetary
demands of departments related to agriculture collectively.

The core objective of Krishi Cabinet is to increase agriculture production and
productivity with the joint efforts of Irrigation, Narmada valley development,
Power distribution, Panchayat and Rural Development, Revenue, Tribal and
Scheduled Caste Development Departments and with their integrated suggestions
and decisions in this regard.

These efforts will be made to bring the smiles on the face of farmers, animal
herders and fish farmers. Besides, the departments like Panchayat and Rural
Development, Water Resources, Narmada Valley Development, Energy, Revenue,
Tribal and Scheduled Caste Development and Forest will take decisions keeping in
view the policy matters of Agriculture, Horticulture, Animal Husbandry, Dairy,
Fish Farming and Cooperatives Departments in order to frame out an integrated
policy for the development.

This Cabinet will also take decisions on planning and budgets of departments
concerned as far as development of these departments relates to agriculture
sectors.

It will decide on short-term and long-term polices in agriculture sector. For
this, suggestions will be sought from experts. The Agriculture Cabinet will be
authorised for ensuring coordination among inter-departmental activities in
order to gain positive results in agriculture sector. The Cabinet will also hold
budgetary discussion on supplementary demands for agriculture and agriculture
sector for developing agriculture budget concept.

State BJP spokesman Vijesh Lunawat said that it was a unique initiative taken by
the Chief Minister who has always been concerned towards the farming community.

On the contrary, the main opposition Congress has termed this as old wine in new
bottle. There was no need to form a separate Cabinet for agriculture because
Agriculture Department was already functional in the State along with other
departments. State Congress spokesman JP Dhanopia said, "If the Chief Minister
wanted to introduce a separate Cabinet for Agriculture, he should have abolished
the defunct Agriculture Department and sacked the Agriculture Minister."

Recommendations

The State Government is committed to bringing about a second green revolution by
increasing agriculture production in Madhya Pradesh. All the sectors related to
agriculture will be strengthened in the State. A three-day workshop on
agriculture was orgnaised in Jabalpur last week in which over 300 agriculture
scientists, progressive farmers and officers across the country took the part in
the workshop.

Heads of five panels gave recommendations. Jawaharlal Nehru Agriculture
University Vice-Chancellor Gautam Kallu presented new techniques of agriculture.
Besides, former Director General Indian Agriculture Research Council, New Delhi
Panjab Singh stressed on initiating pilot projects to improve agriculture
sector. He said that natural resources and man-made resources are available but
they should be exploited in right direction.

Rajamata Vijayraje Scindia Agriculture University, Gwalior Vice-Chancellor VS
Tomar underlined the need for publicity of new modern techniques of farming.
Besides, CK Mishra felt the need for agriculture business management
development. He said that there is need to reform the management of Krishi Upaj
Mandi. Former Deputy Director General Indian Agriculture Research Council, New
Delhi Anwar Alam recommended for the upgradation of agriculture research and
education. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For any
query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: June 23, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

IP Australia grants trade mark 'Strzelecki Award ' to FTA Distribution Pty Ltd

LENGTH: 381 words

DATELINE: New York



 Australia: FTA Distribution Pty Ltd , has been granted trademark (1764396)
titled as "Strzelecki Award

 " from -13-APR-2016-, through -13-APR-2026-, from the Australian trademark
office.





 Status: Registered/Protected





 Goods & Services:    Class 1: Bacterial preparations for use in agriculture;
Bacteriological preparations for use in agriculture; Calcium peroxide for use in
agriculture; Chemical adjuvants for use in agriculture; Chemical products for
use in agriculture (other than fungicides, weedkillers, herbicides,
insecticides, parasiticides); Chemically treated peat for use in agriculture;
Chemicals used in agriculture; Gas mixtures for use in agriculture; Gases for
use in agriculture; Lime for use in agriculture; Manure for agriculture; Plastic
alloys for use in agriculture; Protective coatings for agriculture (not
fungicides, weedkillers, herbicides, insecticides or parasiticides); Radioactive
products for use in agriculture; Rock fibres for use in agriculture; Substrates
for soil-free growing (agriculture); Trace elements for use in agriculture;
Chemical additives for fertilisers; Fertilisers; Fertilisers consisting of
compounds of nitrogen; Fish meal fertilisers; Liquid fertilisers; Mulch for soil
enrichment (fertiliser); Nitrogenous fertilisers; Organic digestate
(fertiliser); Peat (fertiliser); Phosphates (fertilisers); Salts (fertilisers);
Seaweeds (fertilisers); Slag (fertilisers); Superphosphates (fertilisers)



 Class 7: Fertiliser broadcasters (machines); Row fertiliser spreaders
(machines); Two-disc fertiliser spreaders



 Class 44: Consultancy relating to agriculture; Cultivation advisory services
relating to agriculture; Fumigation in agriculture; Insecticide spraying in
agriculture; Pest control in agriculture; Pest exterminating (for agriculture,
horticulture and forestry); Providing information, including online, about
agriculture, horticulture, and forestry services; Vermin exterminating for
agriculture, horticulture and forestry

                      July 21, 2015 Tuesday 11:51 AM  EST

United Kingdom Intellectual Property Office Publishes Application for Trademark
"Root 1 Feeder" to DP Brandco for Various Goods and Services

LENGTH: 1623 words

DATELINE: South Wales


South Wales, July 21 -- DP Brandco Ltd., Manchester, has filed the trademark
"Root 1 Feeder" on June 24, for various goods and services.

The trademark application (journal number: 2015/029) was published on July 17.

                               8 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              Early Times (India)

                            December 6, 2016 Tuesday

JK witnesses 40% drop in Agri share to GDP since 1980

LENGTH: 533 words

DATELINE: Srinagar


Srinagar, Dec. 6 -- As the agriculture land conversion goes unabated in Jammu
and Kashmir, the agriculture share to GDP of the state has declined by 40
percent in last around four decades, officials said.

An official of the agriculture department while quoting official figures said
the agriculture share to GDP of Jammu and Kashmir has declined by 40 percent
since 1980.

Despite decline in agriculture share to the GDP, the Jammu and Kashmir is yet to
implement the 'agriculture policy' that will actualize the vast untapped growth
potential of this sector despite 60 percent population of the state being
directly or indirectly dependent on the agriculture sector.

Several states have implemented the agriculture policy to increase production
and productivity of the crops and to enable farmers to diversify their crop
production so as to take advantage of market opportunities.

However, the government has failed to implement the effective agriculture policy
in the state that will lay down long term road map for improvisation of
agriculture sector.

"The agriculture policy has been confined to papers only without being
implemented on the ground. Although majority of population are directly or
indirectly dependent on the sector but government has been least interested in
implementing the agriculture policy," the official said. Official sources said a
draft of agriculture policy was framed but authorities were not bothered to
ensure its implementation resulting there has been decline in agriculture
production.

The policy was framed to actualize the vast untapped growth potential of the
agriculture, promote value addition, accelerate the growth of agri-business, and
create employment in rural areas.

The farmers said they have raised the issue with the government several times to
implement the agriculture policy in the state, but to no avail. "Only assurances
have been given to the farmers by the authorities that agriculture policy will
be implemented but no such efforts have been made on the ground," said Ali
Mohammad, a farmer of Anantnag.

Officials said without agriculture policy, the state was unable to take
advantage of several centrally sponsored schemes that would have been beneficial
to boost agriculture crops by introducing high breed seeds, inputs on subsidy
rates besides technical know how to state's farmers.

Kashmir's economy is highly dependent on agriculture, supporting over 60 percent
of its population. Officials said the agriculture policy would have helped in
educating the farmers about the latest technology that is being used in
developed world. The provisions of J&K Land Revenue Act 1996 prohibit the
conversion of paddy or vegetable land into any other use. The construction of
residential and commercial buildings on agricultural land is violation of the
master plan is believed another reason for decline in agriculture production. A
senior official of agriculture department said the government was in the process
in implementing effective agriculture policy.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Early Times. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: December 6, 2016

                               9 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                      East African Business Week (Kampala)

                                August 09, 2015

Regional Talks On Climate Held

LENGTH: 654 words

DATELINE: Kampala


Experts from the Eastern Africa sub-region have launched a new climate-smart
agriculture platform that will aid in scaling up climate-smart agriculture (CSA)
practices in the region.

The Platform will support East African countries to address sub-regional issues
related to Climate-smart agriculture scale up and will contribute to continental
initiatives such as the Africa Climate-Smart Agriculture Alliance and the
AU/NEPAD goal of having 25 million farming households in Africa practicing
climate-smart agriculture by 2025.

Climate smart agriculture is an approach to developing the technical, policy and
investment conditions to achieve sustainable agricultural development for food
security under climate change.

According to experts climate smart Agriculture contributes to the achievement of
national food security.

The climate smart Agriculture platform was launched in Kampala during a two day
workshop hosted by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United
Nations Sub-regional Office for Eastern Africa and the Uganda Climate-Smart
Agriculture Task Force with support from the COMESA-EAC-SADC.

Addressing climate change Experts. Uganda's Minister for Agriculture, Animal
Industry and Fisheries Hon. Tress Bucyanayandi said there is need for drastic
and innovative measures to help the East African countries and Uganda at large
to adapt climate change smart Agriculture.

The Minister said: "Climate change is already affecting food production systems
and therefore the livelihoods and food security of millions of people,
especially women who depend on agriculture for a living are to suffer the
consequences associated with climate change if no Innovation has been
developed."

Bucyanayandi observed that agriculture sector has the biggest potential to
contribute to climate change mitigation either through reducing emissions,
improving production or creating carbon sinks.

He said this can be done by adopting CSA practices such as conservation
agriculture and agroforestry. The meeting brought together participants from
Ministries of Agriculture in five Eastern African Countries in addition to key
Regional Economic Communities such as (EAC and IGAD).

The objective of the meeting was to deliberate on issues around the adoption and
sustained practice of climate-smart agriculture which including monitoring and
evaluation of climate-smart agriculture, value chain development for
climate-smart agriculture, access to equipment for climate-smart agriculture ,
mainstreaming CSA into national agriculture investment plans and the gender
dimensions in promotion of CSA practices among others.

The experts recognized the need for all countries to have functioning national
CSA task forces in order to support a coordinated approach to CSA promotion
efforts at country level.

The experts also welcomed the formation of a Sub-regional CSA Platform that
would take the lead on sub-regional efforts to scale up climate-smart
agriculture.

Making Key note address to the participants, FAO Deputy Country Representative
Mr. Massimo Castiello said the climate-smart agriculture concept which tackles
climate change in an integrated manner should be embraced by developing
countries especially in Africa and EAC in general

Climate Smart Agriculture practices such as conservation agriculture,
agro-forestry, integrated pest management, crop rotation, mulching and residue
management and others, are promising options that, overtime can sustainably
increase the productivity of smaller holder farmers as well as their
profitability and resilience without compromising the environment.

However despite the positive benefits from climate smart practices not widely
used in the Eastern Africa Sub-region, partly because there is limited
awareness, capacity, knowledge and policy support for the widespread use of CSA
technologies. Thus the need by a need to scale up such practices across the
Eastern Africa countries as a whole.

LOAD-DATE: August 10, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2015 AllAfrica Global Media.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              10 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                           September 13, 2016 Tuesday

Guv to experts: Prepare 'future-ready' Agriculture curricula for colleges

LENGTH: 852 words

DATELINE: Raipur


Raipur, Sept. 13 -- Governor Balramji Das Tandon on Monday called upon the
experts to prepare Agriculture course curricula to suit the future needs of the
society which could be implemented in the Agriculture colleges.

He was addressing the eighth Convocation ceremony of the Indira Gandhi
Agriculture University (IGAU) here.

Union Agriculture Minister Radhamohan Singh was the chief guest on the
occasion.Earlier, IGAU Vice-Chancellor Dr S. K. Patil welcomed the gathering.

The Governor while laying stress upon the organic farming said that a road map
should be prepared by which the farmers should be benefitted by adopting
Bio-farming (Organic farming).

There should be minimum usage of chemical fertilisers and more usage of
Bio-pesticides and organic manures, he said.

Tandon said that farmers had been facing stiff competition because of global
agriculture market scenario. "It is imperative to update the knowledge of
markets to the farmers."

The products should suit the national and global markets and new opportunities
should be tested. Information Technology should be used in the field of
agriculture, the Governor said.

Notably, a total of 1997 students were conferred with degrees at the Convocation
function. Twenty-six students were conferred with Ph.Ds and 15 meritorious
students with Gold Medals.

Union Minister Radhamohan Singh expressed his satisfaction that the lone
Agriculture University in Chhattisgarh had inked more than 40 MoUs with leading
institutions regarding research works.

The Union Minister stressed upon the need for increasing the production of
pulses and oilseeds. Under the 'Mera Gaon-Mera Gourav' Mission, Indian Council
of Agriculture Research and Agriculture universities had adopted 10,000
villages.

He revealed that 'Kisan Pratham' scheme will also be introduced at IGAU soon.
"This will act as a medium between the farmers and the farm scientists. In
2015-16, about 50,000 farmers had direct discussions with hundred leading
institutes and Agriculture universities."

Chief Minister Raman Singh said that the youth who had been conferred with
degrees today will enter new phase of life soon.

He appreciated that youth in Chhattisgarh had been showing a keen interest in
agriculture of late.

When the entire world is running after 'White Collar' jobs, the youth in the
State are showing interest in farm sector, he said.

Singh urged the students to help increase farm output. The seats in Engineering
Colleges are going abegging but the Agriculture colleges are in great demand.
One out of ten students is opting for Agriculture colleges.

He revealed that there were times when agriculture sector became stagnant. But
new research had increased farm production. To increase output is a very big
challenge. While remembering famous Chhattisgarh Agriculture scientist Dr R H
Richaria, the Chief Minister revealed that the former had assembled 23,000
varieties of paddy Germplasm. The scenario on the agriculture front from Bijapur
to Dantewada and Balrampur district had changed dramatically in recent times,
the Chief Minister stated.

'Mocho-Badi' organic farming is a unique experiment being carried on in
Dantewada district. Several steps are being undertaken in the field of
Agriculture education in Chhattisgarh, he said.

In the year 2000, there was just one Agriculture college, one Animal Husbandry
and one Dairy Technology college. Now there are 12 Government Colleges and two
Horticulture Colleges at present. There are several private agriculture colleges
also in operation. Earlier irrigation capacity was only 23 per cent and now it
is 34 per cent, Singh said.

State Agriculture Minister Brijmohan Agrawal said that maximum employment is
provided in the farm sector. The biggest Agriculture Museum in the entire
country was inaugurated on the IGAU campus today.

Agrawal threw light upon the achievements of the Agriculture University during
the past 29 years. Several Agriculture Science Centres had been opened under the
jurisdiction of IGAU.

Many posts had been filled up and there was a boost provided to research work.
Chhattisgarh is the only State in the entire country that provides loans up to
Rs 25 lakh to Agriculture graduates to open Agriculture Science Centre, he said.

There are 500 Agriculture Science Centres in the State at present. These centres
had been opened in 21 out of 27 districts with the co-operation of the Central
Government, he said.

In the programme presided over by Governor Balramji Das Tandon, Union
Agriculture and Farmer Welfare Minister Radhamohan Singh also inaugurated
Agriculture Museum building worth Rs 4 .92 crore and commenced Agriculture
Science Centre approved for Raipur district at IGAU campus.

It is noteworthy that Agriculture Museum in Raipur is the biggest in the
country, whereas the Agriculture Science Centre inaugurated is the 21st centre
of Chhattisgarh. For this, 50 acres of lakh has been allotted in IGAU premises,
official informed.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              11 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                    The Daily Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           January 13, 2016 Wednesday

Nominations sought for state Excellence in Agriculture Awards

BYLINE: From Staff Reports

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 546 words


In 1998, the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture was created
to recognize those who have helped lead the industry while demonstrating
exemplary personal values and pursuing agricultural achievements. Through Feb.
12, the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry is accepting
nominations for Oklahoma Excellence in Agriculture Awards.The award winners will
be announced during a recognition ceremony March 30 at the state Capitol as part
of the state's Oklahoma Ag Day celebration.Examples of eligible agriculture
enterprises for the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture
nominee are: livestock and crop production, agribusiness, forestry, horticulture
and nursery management.

In addition to considering the nominee's production agriculture involvement, the
application recognizes leadership in agricultural and state organizations as
well as additional awards and honors. The winner will be someone with at least
25 years in agriculture who derives the bulk of his or her income from
agriculture or has retired from an agricultural enterprise.Previous award
winners have represented different areas of Oklahoma as well as a variety of
agricultural groups and commodities. Past recipients have guided their families
and communities to success by excelling as dairymen, cattle ranchers, pork
producers, wheat farmers, conservationists and educators.Award categoriesIn
addition to the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture, the
department&nbsp;presents the Agriculture Environmental Stewardship Award,
Outstanding Legacy in Agriculture Award and Outstanding Public Service in
Agriculture Award.&nbsp;Gov. Mary Fallin's Agriculture Environmental Stewardship
Award recognizes Oklahoma agriculturalists who are leaders in developing and
adopting outstanding environmentally innovative agricultural practices. This
award will highlight the efforts of an Oklahoma agriculture producer who is a
steward of the environment and is dedicated to conserving the natural resources
of Oklahoma while helping to ensure a continued supply of food and
fiber.Fallin's Outstanding Public Service in Agriculture Award honors an
individual who has made outstanding contributions of public service to Oklahoma
agriculture. The recipient will be someone who works diligently to improve
public perception of agriculture in Oklahoma. The recipient should be a person
who has given time and talent unselfishly to advance the Oklahoma agricultural
industry.Fallin's Outstanding Legacy to Agriculture Award posthumously honors
someone who made significant lifelong contributions to Oklahoma agriculture."The
Oklahoma Excellence in Agriculture Awards give us the opportunity to recognize
those individuals who have made a positive and lasting impact on agriculture in
our state," said Oklahoma Secretary of Agriculture Jim Reese.The deadline for
all nominations is 5 p.m. Feb. 12. Recipients will be selected by a committee of
representatives from agricultural commodity organizations and farm and ranch
organizations.To learn moreQuestions about the nomination procedure or
completion of the official nomination form can be directed to Jason Harvey at
522-5563. The nomination forms can be found online at
www.ag.ok.gov/odaff-halloffame.htm.

LOAD-DATE: January 14, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


            Copyright 2016 The Daily Oklahoman, All Rights Reserved

                               Business Recorder

                            November 9, 2015 Monday

China shows interest in upgrading agriculture sector

SECTION: Vol. LI No. 307

LENGTH: 284  words


Peoples Republic of China has showed deep interest in upgrading agriculture
industrial sector, developing most mechanism of modern agriculture machinery and
seed industries in collaboration with Chinese experts boosting up and
strengthening the agriculture sector across the country particularly in
agriculture producing areas, agriculture officials said on Saturday.

The five members' Chinese delegation led by province Jilin's Vice Director
General Agriculture Commission Wang Xiang visited a few days back. The
delegation was comprised of Jilin Agriculture Commissions' Baoshan Howa Division
head foreign economic division Xiang Xee, Jilin People's government foreign
office interpreter Wang Lin, Jilin Ping Aan Seed Company Limited Chief Executive
Officer Yang Ti Ching Jilin Kongda Agriculture Machinery Company Ltd general
manager.

Agriculture officials said the delegation met with Punjab Director General
Agriculture (Field) Dr Qurban Ali Sindhu and held meeting with the
representatives of agriculture machinery manufacturing companies. The Chinese
delegation was briefed on agriculture machinery manufacturing in Pakistan.

The Chinese delegation also visited Faislabad Chak 34/GB Naseer agriculture farm
and reviewed agriculture cropping and assessed the demonstration of agriculture
machinery. The Chinese delegation also visited agriculture machinery
manufacturing units.

Talking to this scribe Punjab Agriculture Information assistant Director Naveed
Asmat Kahloon said that China has showed interest in developing seed processing
and upgrading the agriculture machinery infrastructure.

He said the Chinese expertise would bring revolution in Punjab agriculture and
increasing the per acre yield.

                              14 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                           September 3, 2009 Thursday

Planning Commission committed for fast-track agriculture development

LENGTH: 433  words


Chairman Planning Commission of Pakistan, Sardar Aseff Ahmed Ali said on
Wednesday that the Commission was committed to helping fast track development of
agriculture sector on modern lines.

He was speaking at a workshop on Innovative Development Strategies organized by
Pakistan Agriculture Research Council with support from the World Bank and Food
and Agriculture Organization here.

Secretary Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Zia-ur-Rehman was also present on
the occasion. He stressed the need for conducting research to put the
agriculture on the progressive path, saying that the government would provide
all out support and incentives for conducting agriculture research to enhance
productivity and export of agriculture produce.

He said that the government, in the federal budget for 2009-10 had allocated a
huge amount for the development of agriculture sector. He said that the
agriculture sector has been neglected since long and that is why people move
towards urban areas and industrialization instead of investing in agriculture.

He lamented that despite being among top countries producing agriculture yields,
Pakistan's agriculture exports were very low. He said that levying tax on
agriculture sector was totally provincial subject and said that the federal
government should let the provinces collect these revenues.

Speaking on the occasion, Chairman PARC Zafar Altaf said that Pakistan was
lagging behind in agriculture productivity, saying that Chinese farmers have
been producing much more yield from per acre land than farmers in Pakistan.

He stressed the need for formulating longstanding policies, with particular
focus on research to ensure sustainable development of agriculture sector.
Earlier, in her detailed presentation on "The Terms of Trade (ToTs) for
Pakistan's Agriculture and Agriculture Income Tax," Safiya Aftab, an agriculture
expert stressed the need for working on a fair pricing structure for agriculture
products.

She highlighted the issues of agriculture tax and said that some serious
research was needed on imposition of an agriculture income tax while saying that
although agriculture tax would enhance government's revenues but it would not
have poverty inducing effects.

Another expert, Idrees Khawaja said that Public Private Partnership (PPP) has
not delivered due to inadequate research prior to launching the project, heavily
weighted by public sector considerations and ineffective planning.  Khalid Riaz,
another expert from private sector gave a detailed briefing on "An Analysis of
Pakistan's Revealed Comparative Advantage in Agriculture Products."

                              All Rights Reserved


                              15 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             The News International

                           December 10, 2016 Saturday

Growth linked to cooperative farming

SECTION: Vol. 26 No. 277

LENGTH: 465  words


There is a need to promote cooperative farming for the growth of agriculture and
economic progress besides evolving a comprehensive policy for bright future of
agriculture.

These views were expressed by the participants in Jang Economic Session on 'when
agriculture sector situation will be better'. The panellists were Muhammad Ayub,
Rabia Sultan, Dr Anjum Buttar, Tayyab Ali Khan, Mian Fazal Ahmed, and Dr Bilal
Sufi while hosted by Sikandar Lodhi.

Muhammad Ayub said collectively agriculture sector was growing and Pakistan had
become self-sufficient in five major crops. He said cooperative farming could
increase agriculture productivity and national income while practical steps were
required to promote research in agriculture sector. He called for a
comprehensive policy for the agriculture sector besides promoting value addition
rather than giving price support and subsidies.

Rabia Sultan said the importance of agriculture sector in Pakistan's economy was
crucial but there was a need to correct its direction. She said due to lack of
investments in agriculture infrastructure during the last three decades sector
was in loss and billion of dollars worth water wasted every year. She called for
medium and long-term policies for water storage construction along with giving
special incentives to agriculture scientists. She said marketing of agriculture
produce was also the need of the hour which was ignored by successive
governments.

Dr Anjum Buttar said that Punjab had 70 percent of national agriculture produce
of international standards. He said agriculture sector faced issues, including
environment, water shortage and others which hampered its growth potential while
high diesel cost had adversely affected the cost of production. He said the
government was working with FAO and World Bank for agriculture reforms which was
increasing the crops productivity and was likely to increase further in next
three years. Adoption of IT in agriculture sector will pave the way for
accountability and reforms, he observed.

Tayyab Ali Khan said that research on agriculture sector continued in Pakistan.
He said agriculture policy should be made in accordance with the ground
realities to achieve better results. The world has become global shelf and needs
to work in those lines to promote local agriculture produce globally.

Mian Fazal Ahmed said that Pakistan was far behind to achieve agriculture
produce targets despite the fact that nature had bestowed it with all resources
while agriculture exports were less than one percent of the world. He called for
adopting 21st century needs for the development of agriculture sector to resolve
the sector issues. Dr Bilal Sufi said Pakistan's agriculture sector was not
facing production issues but lacking behind in agriculture policy.

                              16 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              Early Times (India)

                            August 27, 2015 Thursday

Agriculture Deptt aghast over Incharge Director appointment

LENGTH: 946 words

DATELINE: Srinagar


Srinagar, Aug. 27 -- The recently appointed new incharge Director Agriculture
Kashmir Syed Altaf Aijaz Andrabi has been placed over and above scores of
seniors in the agriculture production department including Jitender Sharma the
senior most officer confirmed in district cadre by the competent authority. He
occupied the position of Incharge Director Agriculture for more than three
months and was replaced by Haroon Malik a senior KAS Officer only three months
ago.

Meanwhile, senior officers of the agriculture department while seeking immediate
revocation of order appointing Altaf Aijaz Andrabi as incharge director
agriculture Kashmir have alleged that two juniors have been appointed incharge
director agriculture Kashmir and incharge director command area development to
derail the process of departmental promotion committee started for legal
promotions strictly as per seniority. However, minister for agriculture Ghulam
Nabi Lone Hanjura when contacted said that Syed Altaf Aijaz Andrabi will hold
the charge as director agriculture Kashmir just for a month or two till the
final seniority of officers is finalized and the possibility of appointing
senior most officers as full fledged director agriculture Kashmir will be
explored. Highly placed sources said while Jitender Sharma the present Joint
Director Agriculture Inputs (Kashmir) the senior most officer of the Agriculture
Production department is the only officer confirmed by competent authority in
the district cadre, the newly appointed Director Agriculture Kashmir Syed Altaf
Aijaz Andrabi recruited as village extension worker in the year 1984 was
promoted as Agriculture Extension Officer and equivalent on the recommendations
of J&K Public Service Commission vide Commission's letter no:
PSC/DPC/agri/10/2011?dated, 04022013 by the agriculture department vide order
no:113 agri of 2013?dated: 19032013 with retrospective effect from October 1988.
Sources said important to notice for the government was the position of Syed
Altaf Aijaz Andrabi in the overall senior list and the seniority list of village
extension workers in the promotion seniority list of Agriculture Extension
Officers issued vide order no:113 agri of 2013?dated: 19032013. Sources further
revealed that Andrabi stands at S.No:460 in the overall seniority list at at
S.No 36 in the promotion seniority list of the agriculture extension officers
issued vide order no: :113 agri of 2013?dated: 19032013 with retrospective
effect from October 1988. It is in placed to mention here that while inhouse
officers appointed as directors in the agriculture had to go on the charges of
corruption and administrative irregularities, the senior KAS officers appointed
as directors of agriculture department had almost brought the department back on
rails. The fear gripping the employees in agriculture department is the revival
of financial and administrative irregularities witnessed during the reigns of
two former inhouse directors Gh Haider Bhat and Bashir Ahmed Dar. Interestingly
both Gh Haider Bhat and Bashir Ahmed Dar had to face the proceedings before the
anticorruption courts where cases against them were challaned by State Vigilance
Organization (SVO). However Government stung a surprise in last week's cabinet
decision by virtue of which Haroon Malik a senior KAS officer known for his
professional integrity and uprightness was unceremoniously attached with General
Administration Department and Syed Altaf Aijaz Andrabi was asked to look after
the charge of Director Agriculture Kashmir to supercede scores of seniors
including ex incharge director agriculture Kashmir presently holding the charge
of joint director agriculture inputs Kashmir. The other seniors superceded by
Syed Altaf Aijaz Andrabi are Mubarak Reshi 1981 batch officer presently Joint
Director Agriculture (Mushroom), Gh Hassan Guroo 1983 batch officer presently
Joint Director Agriculture (Engineering), S.R. Galotra 1983 batch Officer of
Scheduled Cast category presently, Sudesh Koul 1979 batch officer presently
Joint Director Agriculture (Inputs) Jammu , Sambyal 1983 batch officer presently
Joint Director Fertilizers and Ab Rahim Samoon of Schedule Tribe category 1988
batch officer presently Joint Director Rakhs & Farms. When contacted minister
for agriculture Ghulam Nabi Lone Hanjura told "Syed Altaf Aijaz Andrabi is a
competent and capable officer but we are working on finalization of the
seniority list of officers. He will hold the charge of Director Agriculture
Kashmir just for a month or two till the seniority list of officers is
finalized. The senior most officers will be appointed as full fledged director
agriculture Kashmir but there is no bar on the government that only the senior
most officers is to be appointed as director agriculture Kashmir. In past we had
some KAS officers also who were appointed as director agriculture Kashmir. We
will resolve the issue in a month or two. Meanwhile senior officers of the
agriculture department have condemned the engagement of two juniors Syed Altaf
Aijaz Andrabi and Ashok Malhotra as in charge director agriculture Kashmir and
incharge director command area development Jammu respectively. Warning the
government of dire consequences the officers have immediate revocation of the
said controversial orders which according them have derailed the process of
genuine and legitimate promotion strictly as per seniority through a process
kick started by the departmental promotion committee.

respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              17 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                      Abbotsford Times (British Columbia)

                              May 4, 2010 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Agriculture . . . Abbotsford's economic strength; Enjoy that ever-present sweet
smell of success

BYLINE: David D. Hull, Special to the Times

SECTION: THE CHAMBER VOICE; Executive Director's Soapbox; Pg. CV3

LENGTH: 734  words


Agriculture in Abbotsford is not the "poor farmer" and his family scratching out
a subsistence existence off the land. Agriculture is a wealth-creation industry.
As a primary industry, in the same vein as forestry, mining, fishing, oil and
gas, and tourism, agriculture creates wealth and grows the economy at a rate
significantly higher than value added industries or economic activities that
contribute to the GDP.

AGRICULTURE IS BIG BUSINESS IN ABBOTSFORD

There is a continuing widening of the agriculture knowledge gap along the rural
urban divide amongst Abbotsford residents, that creates a diminishing
recognition that agriculture is a true business in the traditional definition
and perception.

Agriculture is, by a significant amount, the largest sector of Abbotsford's
economy. Economic development trends show that no single industry sector is
likely to surpass agriculture within the short or long-term.

Abbotsford is the most industrious agricultural community in the province and,
in fact, the entire country. Abbotsford is home to more than 1,300 farms with
22,500 hectares of land under active cultivation.

A 2008 report prepared by the Abbotsford Chamber of Commerce, in partnership
with the B.C. Ministry of Agriculture, values the economic effect of agriculture
/agri-business in Abbotsford at $1.8 billion annually.

This value represented 20 per cent of the economic activity in the city. In
addition to significant dollar values, agriculture and agri-business created one
in four private sector jobs and one in five of all jobs in the city.

In fact, not only is agriculture big business in Abbotsford it is the largest
concentration of agriculture, measured both by output and dollar value, in
Canada.

Abbotsford is the agriculture capital of Canada.

The complete report can be found at www.abbotsfordchamber.com.

LAND IN RELATIONSHIP TO THE ECONOMIC EFFECT OF AGRICULTURE

Agriculture, by its very nature, is a land-based industry. Ground crops and
livestock operations consume vast areas. Condensed, mainly housed agriculture
operations like poultry, greenhouse, and mushrooms can be very successful and
sustainable on a relatively small foot print of land, often as small as five
acres, relative to their economic output.

The ability of agriculture to grow and develop in the future depends directly on
the quantity, quality and proximity of agriculture land available for expansion.

As with any industry, sustainable growth is a constant and desired objective.

The agriculture industry in Abbotsford is rapidly becoming constrained from
further growth, and by extrapolation additional contribution to the economy, due
to agriculture appropriate lands being permanently diverted to non agriculture
applications.

AGRICULTURE LAND IN ABBOTSFORD

Abbotsford has some of the richest soils in Canada if not all of North America.
The fertile soil, combined with a temperate climate, and an abundance of
reliable water sources creates an ideal location for extensive soil and non-soil
based agriculture.

Agricultural land is, like the adage about water front property, "They are not
making any more of it." Certainly not in the short-term, practical, reality.

As agriculture is a primary wealth creating industry, dependent on a secure and
affordable land base, any erosion of agriculture lands should be a concern and
not undertaken without significant study, consultation and measure of the net
economic effect. Every hectare of land that is diverted to non-wealth generating
agriculture uses has a significant effect on the economy of Abbotsford.

AGRICULTURE IS ESSENTIALL RECESSION PROOF

Abbotsford weathered the world wide economic downturn, that we are just now
emerging from, far less battered and bruised than essentially any other
jurisdiction in Canada. We are especially fortunate in that Canada survived the
whole economic collapse far better than any other country in the world.

Abbotsford's economic resilience can be directly contributed to the stable and
consistent nature of the agriculture industry. As tough as things might be,
folks still need to eat.

A diversity of domestic and export markets coupled with a wide product range
allowed the largest sector of Abbotsford's economy to hardly miss a beat while
the rest of the world was watching their financial position plummet.

The next time there is an "au d' farm" drifting across the valley just remember,
that odour truly is, the smell of money.

LOAD-DATE: May 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Business; Column

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2010 Abbotsford Times
                              All Rights Reserved

                          The Woodward News (Oklahoma)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           February 5, 2015 Thursday

Nominations open for agriculture awards

BYLINE: Kevin Weiss Staff Writer, The Woodward News, Okla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 483 words


Feb. 05--Whether they work as dairymen, cattle ranchers, pork producers, or
wheat farmers, thousands of people in the agriculture industry work hard every
day to contribute to the growth and production of commodities in Oklahoma.

To celebrate the achievements and sacrifices of those in the agriculture
business, the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry (ODAFF) is
accepting nominations for the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in
Agriculture along with the introduction of three new awards through Feb 13.

"There are four different awards, but basically, these are all for leaders in
the industry who exemplify personal values, performance and achievement in
Oklahoma agriculture," said ODAFF Market Development Director Jamey Allen.

In 1998, the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award was created to recognize
those who have helped lead the agriculture industry while demonstrating strong
character.

"The Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture gives us the
opportunity to recognize those individuals who have made a positive and lasting
impact on agriculture in our state," said Oklahoma Secretary of Agriculture Jim
Reese.

The winner of the Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture will
have a framed plaque installed in the Oklahoma Agriculture Hall of Fall display
that's seated inside the ODAFF headquarters in Oklahoma City.

"That's our major award," Allen declared. "Governor Fallin will be presenting
that award to one individual that's really stood out and been in the industry
more than 25 years."

The three new awards being presented for the first time include the Agriculture
Environmental Stewardship Award, Outstanding Public Service in Agriculture Award
and the Outstanding Legacy in Agriculture Award.

"We wanted to take the opportunity to recognize others that excelled in
agriculture fields with different opportunities," said Allen. "They will be
selected by a Governor's Selection Committee."

The Environmental Stewardship Award will recognize an agricultural producer that
has adopted environmentally innovative practices, while the Public Service in
Agriculture Award will recognize someone who works diligently to improve the
public perception of the agriculture industry.

The Legacy in Agriculture Award is the only award strictly for posthumous
nominees who have made significant life-long contributions to Oklahoma
agriculture.

"There will be an awards ceremony on Ag Day, that'll be April 1st," Allen
explained. "It'll be held at the state Capitol in Room 535."

Examples of eligible nominees include those involved in livestock and crop
production, agribusiness, forestry, horticulture and nursery management.

Nomination forms can be found at www.ag.ok.gov/odaff-halloffame.htm

___ (c)2015 The Woodward News (Woodward, Okla.) Visit The Woodward News
(Woodward, Okla.) at woodwardnews.net Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC

                              19 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            The Times of India (TOI)

                           November 5, 2011 Saturday

With more jobs, demand for agriculture courses picks up

BYLINE: Rajendrakumar K R

SECTION: MYSORE

LENGTH: 518 words


MANDYA: With increasing job opportunities in agro-based industries and the need
to produce more agriculture graduates to help farmers improve crop yield,
'agricultural courses' seem to be the most sought after option by students these
days.

Agriculture education has snow-balled due to its numerous job openings as well
as the agriculture sector getting new inevitable dimensions over the recent
years. Owing to rapid growth and unexpected developments in the agriculture
sector in India, lakhs of jobs are being generated for graduates in agriculture
and its allied areas like fertilizers, chemical manufacturing industries, seeds
industry, food technology, agri-banking etc. Moreover, the decreasing arable
land due to rapid urbanization and poor soil structure, crop yields are also
seeing a decrease. To address these issues, agriculture scholarly persons are in
demand to help farmers to increase crop output on their crumpled fields through
scientific ways.

All these factors have instilled confidence among students opting for
agriculture courses. In a significant change, meritorious students are now
joining agriculture courses. Talking to TOI, V T Sannaveerappanavar, dean of
Agriculture College, V C Farm in Mandya, said agriculture education has assumed
much importance for various reasons. According to him, this education sector may
be the only one that does not have unemployment problems.

Sannaveerappanavar said that the Agriculture College, V C Farm, which is
affiliated to Bangalore Agriculture University, offers a four-year BSc course in
agriculture. Besides this, the college has started two new diploma courses for
students from rural backgrounds and farm input dealers respectively. The
two-year diploma course in agriculture is offered to students who have passed
SSLC examinations. Another diploma course with duration of one year is offered
to farm input dealers seeking a diploma in agriculture extension services.
Degree courses like BSc in forestry, horticulture, agriculture biotechnology,
agriculture macro, sericulture, BTech in agriculture engineering and food
sciences, are offered at the Bangalore Agriculture University, he added.

"Not even a single agriculture graduate is unemployed due to non availability of
jobs anywhere in the state. We need more agriculture graduates to meet the new
and old versions of problems like crop diseases, soil erosion and diminishing
soil fertility. However, their numbers are very minimal," said
Sannaveerappanavar.

"I have for opted agriculture course to help farmers. Since my childhood days, I
dreamt to serve the country. My first choice was medical profession. However,
due to some reasons I failed to get into medical education. But, now I feel
proud to have opted for the agriculture course, as it has more service
potentiality," said Asha Nayar, a meritorious student from Kerala studying in
second year BSc agriculture.

"I want to educate my village people about the judicious use of water in my
parched Kolar district after completing my course," said Archana, second year
BSc agriculture student.

                              20 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                             March 27, 2011 Sunday

The ag gender gap: Women in Mississippi find myriad of opportunities in
agriculture industry

BYLINE: Wally Northway

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 851  words


Certainty is hard to come by. The only thing certain in Lindsey Ellzey's life is
uncertainty. A farmer in Jones County, Ellzey feels there ought to be more
awareness of and support for women in agriculture in Mississippi, and she is one
of many females in agriculture-related endeavors welcoming the upcoming
Mississippi Women for Agriculture Conference at Mississippi State in Starkville.

"I wake up every day and wonder what hat I am going to be asked to wear," said
Ellzey, who along with her husband, Jason, runs a mixed farming operation of
poultry, cattle and blueberries. "Jason tells me all the time that he depends on
me to help make decisions about our operations. I'm not just a bookkeeper - I am
part of the decision-making process. "

Joan Thompson took a break from her work to speak to the Mississippi Business
Journal for this story. She was busy with her apiary near Philadelphia, which is
in the process of being expanding from 125 beehives to 200.

"There is no better place to raise a family than on a farm," Thompson said. She
is a member of the Mississippi Farm Bureau Federation's Women's Committee, and
said more needs to be done to encourage women to look at agriculture as a viable
career. "I don't have any female friends who are farmers. We have to do more to
encourage them," she added.

Ellzey, who is also active with the Farm Bureau Federation, said she, too, has
no female farmer-friends, and education is much needed. "When I first started
promoting the Farm Bureau, most people in this area thought they were only about
insurance," she said.

Both Ellzey and Thompson expressed their support for the Women for Agriculture
Conference, which will be held April 12-14 at the Bost Extension Center on the
Starkville campus of Mississippi State University. This is not the
organization's first conference, but it does mark something of a beginning.

Mississippi Women for Agriculture is a continuation of the MSU and partners'
Women in Agriculture education program. The group looks to increase the
knowledge and skills of women in all aspects of farm and agribusiness management
through educational and networking opportunities.

Sylvia Clark, vice president of Mississippi Women for Agriculture, said her
association began as Women in Agriculture a couple of years ago, funded by a
grant that has since expired. So, the group is reorganizing. It has established
bylaws and changed its name to Mississippi Women for Agriculture.

"We changed the name from Women in Agriculture to Women for Agriculture to
stress that there are plenty of agriculture-related careers available to women
beyond the farm," Clark said. "The mission of the organization is helping women
understand different aspects of agriculture such as risk management, credit and
marketing. "

Among the many activities planned for the Starkville conference include election
of new officers of Women for Agriculture (previous officers were volunteers),
presentation of the Dianne Evans Lecture Award, networking and a forestry tour.

New this year is a forum of the candidates for Mississippi's next agriculture
commissioner. Candidates Max Phillips, Dannie Reed and Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith
have already committed to attend.

If Hyde-Smith were elected, she would be Mississippi's first female agriculture
commissioner. Hyde-Smith, who runs a three-state cattle operation headquartered
in Brookhaven, said she knows if elected she would help open women's eyes that
agriculture is a viable career for them, and that she "feels the responsibility.
"

"I want to promote agriculture in general, but I feel even more responsibility
for our female farmers," Hyde-Smith said. "I want to help raise the comfort
level of women when it comes to agriculture.

"Usually, unless a woman is raised on a farm she never considers agriculture as
a career. They see it as a male-dominated field. In a way, agriculture has an
image problem. "

Dr. Maifan Silitonga agrees. She is currently serving as interim director of
Alcorn State University's School of Agriculture, Research, Extension and Applied
Sciences, or AREAS.

In her role, she advises farmers about water quality and how it effects
agriculture production. Silitonga says she sees few females in her education
programs, which does not surprise her. What does have her concerned, however, is
that women largely do not understand that there are a myriad of opportunities
for women in agriculture beyond just running a farm.

"I am a woman in agriculture, but I don't go out and farm. I got my Ph.D. so I
wouldn't have to do that," Silitonga said with a laugh. "There are so many
opportunities for women beyond ag production. I am an example. "

Silitonga said women have skills that fit well in agriculture - attention to
detail, ability to multi-task and nurturing.

When asked if electing a female agriculture commissioner would help raise
awareness among women of agriculture as a career, Silitonga expressed some
reservations.

"I was hired here for my ability," Silitonga said. "It had nothing to with my
gender. Personally, I want an agriculture commissioner who is effective. I don't
care about gender. "

LOAD-DATE: April 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              21 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                           December 31, 2015 Thursday

UPCAR demands to set up agriculture commission

LENGTH: 714 words

DATELINE: Lucknow


Lucknow, Dec. 31 -- UP council of agriculture Research (UPCAR) has demanded from
the state government to set up agriculture commission and also ensure
remunerative minimum support price for the agriculture produce.

The director general of the UPCAR Dr Rajendra Kumar said here on Wednesday that
the state government should set up agriculture commission to look into the
problem o f the farmers and suggest long terms corrective measures. He said the
commission even with one year term should be set up by the government.

The DG regretted that the state government has either ignored or taken no action
on the large number of recommendations made by the UPCAR for the improvement in
the agriculture sector. He said in protest against the government indifference
he had tendered his resignation but was persuaded by the chairman to withdraw. "
The state government tells us that your job is to give the recommendations and
it's our discretion whether to act or not'', said the DG.

Regretting the delay in enactment of the "UP State agriculture university Bill
2014, the DG said the bill has suffered inordinate delay due to the indifference
of the state bureaucracy and government. he said the "UP state agriculture
universities bill 2014' aims to promote training extension programme and
research in agriculture sector. UPCAR, the apex body for coordinating the
research and development among various state agriculture universities and also
funding the development activities.

"We are a toothless organization with huge responsibilities but no authority to
execute the work. If some university or the agriculture college funded by us
fails to perform we can only refer the matter to the state government which in
turn never takes any action'', said the DG.

"A cursory analysis of the work done by the vice chancellors reveals that the
career of the agriculture scientists is ruined even for small lapses while the
bureaucrats goes scot free even after committing lapses of monumental scale. A
bureaucrats takes important decisions in a closed room and they are endorsed at
every level of the government even if they are not in the interest of the people
and actually end up in harming the interest of the state'', said Dr Rajendra
Kumar.

Lamenting the indifference of the bureaucracy towards the "draft bill' the DG
said " the first draft of the bill was drafted as per the recommendation of Dr
Saroja Raman committee report and sent to the state government in 19956, the
government decided to review the bill and set up one more committee. Another
committee was set up by the government in 2010 and a revised 'draft bill' was
sent to the government which returned the draft bill''.

"In 2013 the Agriculture production commissioner set up high level task force to
draft fresh bill. Fresh bill was vetted by the Indian council of agriculture
research, Agriculture Science congress and all the vice chancellors of state
agriculture universities and sent to the state government in October 2014. The
principal secretary of the agriculture department is not willing to cede its
powers to the agriculture scientists and adamant on maintaining the dominance of
the bureaucracy on agriculture education and research. The fate of the bill is
still hanging in balance'', said the DG UPCAR.

He said the present law "UP state agriculture and technology university act 1958
is 58 years old and most of its provision have turned archaic and needs
immediate revision to make it relevant as the technology at all level of
agriculture and farming has undergone a sea change. He said the 'draft bill'
pending with the state government, if Legislated will go a long way in improving
the education standards in state agriculture universities and colleges and also
give a boost to the agriculture research. Presently there are 4 agriculture
universities in the state-Kanpur, Meerut, Faizadab and banda and one deemed
university at Allahabad, one veterinary collage at Mathura, 37 agriculture
colleges affiliated with non agriculture state universities and 14 institutions
run by the Indian council of agriculture research.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              22 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                  Daily Times

                            April 13, 2013 Saturday

Devolution of agri subject to provinces still hanging in balance

BYLINE:  Staff Report

SECTION: Vol. X No. 102

LENGTH: 642  words


Despite approval of 18th Amendment in the parliament with emphasis on devolution
of agriculture subject to provinces, the fate of agriculture subject is still
hanging in balance.

Eight subjects which had became redundant have been abolished and 15 major
functions of the Ministry of Food and Agriculture (MinFA) have been separated
and distributed among the federal ministries and departments and there was no
actual devolution of the agriculture subject have taken place to the provinces.

In major industrial and agriculture economies like United States, China, India,
Japan, Korea and England agriculture is the federal subject and full fledge
federal agriculture ministry's are functioning at their federal level.

The reason explained in this regard by the officials is decisions relating to
import and export of agriculture commodities, policy making for agriculture
sector, incentivisation of agriculture sector on equal basis conducting research
extension of this research to farmers needs it to maintain agriculture subject
at federal level.

Two provinces remain surplus in wheat and two always remain in deficit in wheat
production in accordance with their wheat requirements and it is the federal
government which ensures arrangement of agriculture commodities for the deficit
provinces from surplus provinces through local production or imports, explained
the officials.

The official explained Department of Plant Protection, Agriculture Policy
Institute, Pakistan Agriculture Research Council, Pakistan Central Cotton
Committee, coordination among marine and fisheries departments, protection and
monitoring of crops from pest and other attacks, developing different verities
of seeds for batter production of crops, experiments of different verities of
seeds of different crops in different provinces and other important initiatives
need federal level involvement in agriculture affairs.

The other justifications for maintaining agriculture subject at federal level,
as explained by the officials is nine international organisations relating to
agriculture like FAO, IFAD, UNICEF and agriculture departments of major
economies having strong interest in agriculture always coordinate with federal
governments instead of units of a federation.

Not a single province has the capacity to coordinate with these international
organisations and they still need federal coordination between them.

Similarly the distribution of water for agriculture is federal subject with
Indus River System Authority as federal regulator and this is vital for ensuring
equal opportunities for each federating unit to get due share of water for its
agriculture with involvement of centre for ensuring food security at national
level.

Constitution of Pakistan is still silent on the issue of agriculture, weather it
would remain with centre or to be transferred to the provinces, said the
official sources.

The officials at Ministry of Food Security and Planning Commission believed at
the time of the preparation of the 18th Amendment, the official concerned
remained unable to defend the retaining the agriculture subject with centre.

Or otherwise, the architects of the 18th Amendment were with a mindset for its
transfer to the provinces without knowing the negative implications on this
productive sector of the economy.

The official sources explained with the creation of Federal Ministry for Food
Security at federal level and no devolution of major functions to provinces have
proved a faulty decision making on the agriculture subject.

The abolishing or deletion of many functions of MinFA while creating of Food
Security Ministry has also resulted in loss of references that were needed and
were available for agriculture growth strategies. This was a vast treasure of
information, data and research that was once available, have been lost in the
decision making process.

LOAD-DATE: April 13, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                           Copyright 2013 Daily Times
                              All Rights Reserved

With more jobs, demand for agriculture courses picks up

                              24 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             The News International

                          September 22, 2016 Thursday

Punjab, WB to ink accord for agriculture development

SECTION: Vol. 26 No. 199

LENGTH: 635  words


A delegation of the World Bank's Agriculture and Rural Transformation Mission
led by Country Director Patchamuthu Illangovan met Chief Minister Shahbaz Sharif
here Wednesday and discussed with him the matters regarding development of
agriculture sector and strengthening of markets for agriculture and rural
transformation in Punjab.

According to a handout, speaking on the occasion, the chief minister said that
Pakistan was an agrarian country and agriculture sector was the backbone of its
economy. He said that development of agriculture sector could help strengthen
national economy and achieve the target of self-sufficiency.

He said that Punjab government would welcome cooperation of the World Bank in
the development of agriculture sector.

He said that provincial government wanted to benefit from the experience of the
World Bank experts for development of agriculture sector and increase in
per-acre yield. He said that an agreement of cooperation would be signed between
Punjab government and the World Bank for development of agriculture sector.

Shahbaz Sharif said that the World Bank was an important partner of Punjab
government in the programme of development of social sectors, and several
programmes were running in the province with its cooperation for the provision
of basic amenities to the masses.

He said that the World Bank was extending commendable cooperation for the
development of social sectors, and measures would be taken to increase its
cooperation in agriculture sector.

The chief minister said that Punjab government had given a historic package of
Rs 100 billion to increase per-acre yield and prosperity of small cultivators.

He said the programme for provision of interest-free loans to small cultivators
had been started and the loans were being given in a highly transparent manner
with the help of modern technology.

Shahbaz Sharif said the Punjab Agriculture Commission had also been established
for development of agriculture sector and solution to the problems of
cultivators while a high-level committee had been constituted for evolving an
agriculture policy. He said that measures were also been taken for the
establishment of Small Farmers Development Corporation.

The chief minister said that future of Punjab was linked with agriculture and
development of agriculture sector could help strengthen the provincial economy.
He said that agriculture research could go a long way in increasing agricultural
production. He said that transfer of results of the latest research to farmers
was of vital importance, therefore, extension services were being activated. He
said that comprehensive reforms were being introduced in the seed industry. He
said that agriculture experts of the World Bank had given excellent
recommendation for the development of agriculture sector in the province and
full benefit would be taken of their experience and skills.

Country Director of the World Bank Patchamuthu Illangovan assured that all-out
cooperation would be extended to Punjab government for development of
agriculture sector. He said that there was a vast potential for development of
agriculture sector in Punjab and the World Bank with work with the provincial
government to fully utilise this potential. He said that the best agriculture
scientists of the world had been appointed in Islamabad, and working with them
would leave a positive impact on agriculture sector in the province.

The World Bank team included Agriculture Senior Director Juregen Voegele and
Agriculture Senior Economist Johannes Georges Pius Jansen.

Provincial Ministers Dr Farrukh Javed, Yawar Zaman, Ayesha Ghaus Pasha, Special
Assistant on Livestock Arshad Jutt, Advisor Dr Ejaz Nabi, chief secretary, Board
of Revenue senior member, Planning and Development chairman and agriculture
experts were also present.

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       August 7, 2015 Friday 6:30 AM EST

Research and Markets: Global and Chinese Agriculture Tractor Industry 2010-2015,
2015-2020

LENGTH: 379  words


Aug. 7 -- Research and Markets
(http://www.researchandmarkets.com/research/rbk3pc/global_and) has announced the
addition of the "Global and Chinese Agriculture Tractor Industry, 2010-2020
Market Research Report" report to their offering.

Market Research Report on Global and Chinese Agriculture Tractor Industry,
2010-2020 is a professional and in-depth market survey on Global and Chinese
Agriculture Tractor industry.

The report firstly reviews the basic information of Agriculture Tractor
including its classification, application and manufacturing technology. The
report then explores global and China's top manufacturers of Agriculture
Tractors listing their product specification, capacity, production value, and
market share etc. The report further analyzes quantitatively 2010-2015 global
and China's total market of Agriculture Tractors by calculation of main economic
parameters of each company.

Scope

* The breakdown data of Agriculture Tractor market are presented by company, by
country, and by application.

* The report also estimates 2015-2020 market development of Agriculture Tractor
Industry.

* The report then analyzes the upstream raw materials, downstream clients, and
current market dynamics of Agriculture Tractor Industry.

* The report makes some proposals for a new project of Agriculture Tractor
Industry and a new project of Agriculture Tractor Industry before evaluating its
feasibility.

* The report provides an in-depth insight of 2010-2015 global and China
Agriculture Tractor industry covering all important parameters.
