Pakistan: Political parties urged to include agriculture reforms in manifestos

LENGTH: 486 words

DATELINE: LAHORE


LAHORE, April 19 -- The political parties have mentioned agriculture in their
election manifestoes 2013 but no practical action was seen to protect it
ignoring the fact that this sector guaranteed the national food security.

These views were expressed by the discussants in Jang Economic Session on 'how
agriculture sector sees the election slogans of the political parties', here on
Wednesday. The panellists were Chairman Economics Department Punjab University
Dr Hafeez-ur-Rehman, Jamshed Cheema, Hamid Malhi, Rukhsana Zafar and Akthar Mayo
while hosted by Sikandar Hameed Lodhi and Intikhab Tariq.

Dr Hafeez-ur-Rehman said that the agriculture sector was providing highest
employment and supplying raw material to industries. He believed that the
policies should be made while keeping the importance of agriculture sector in
sight but political parties tried to run the affairs with ad hoc policies. He
said developed countries people happily pay taxes due to the facilities given to
them while in Pakistan public consider the taxes a burden due to missing
facilities.

Jamshed Cheema said that agriculture ensure food security and provide cheap food
to public so that government should not deal it as business. He said agriculture
sector was facing substandard seeds, taxes, value addition and non-subsidised
agri inputs issues. He said China was making huge money by value addition of
agriculture sector produce but in Pakistan agriculture sector was ignored again
by political parties. He said that the PTI also focused on energy, education and
health sector.

Hamid Malhi said that 16 per cent GST was imposed on agriculture sector while
political parties did not give importance to agriculture sector in their
manifestos. He said PTI had voiced to construct Kalabagh Dam but did not discuss
it in its manifesto while PML-N has mentioned to grant MFN status to India but
did not give plan to compete with strong Indian agriculture sector.

Rukhsana Zafar said that 80 to 90 per cent of rural women were attached with
agriculture sector but political parties ignored them again. She said India has
limited land holding size to 12 acres but their agriculture sector was growing.
She said the political parties should announce agriculture reforms in their
manifestos.

Akthar Mayo said industrial sector was given preference on agriculture sector
since after creation of Pakistan which badly hit the latter. He said agriculture
sector subsidy was limited to few people while political parties just make
promises for agriculture sector growth. He said if agriculture sector would be
given attention Punjab could become house of food. He said agriculture sector
save the country of economic restriction after atomic blasts Published by HT

to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at

                              Daily The Pak Banker

                            April 18, 2013 Thursday

Political parties urged to include agriculture reforms in manifestos

LENGTH: 449  words

DATELINE: LAHORE


The political parties have mentioned agriculture in their election manifestoes
2013 but no practical action was seen to protect it ignoring the fact that this
sector guaranteed the national food security.



These views were expressed by the discussants in Jang Economic Session on 'how
agriculture sector sees the election slogans of the political parties', here on
Wednesday. The panellists were Chairman Economics Department Punjab University
Dr Hafeez-ur-Rehman, Jamshed Cheema, Hamid Malhi, Rukhsana Zafar and Akthar Mayo
while hosted by Sikandar Hameed Lodhi and Intikhab Tariq.

Dr Hafeez-ur-Rehman said that the agriculture sector was providing highest
employment and supplying raw material to industries. He believed that the
policies should be made while keeping the importance of agriculture sector in
sight but political parties tried to run the affairs with ad hoc policies. He
said developed countries people happily pay taxes due to the facilities given to
them while in Pakistan public consider the taxes a burden due to missing
facilities.

Jamshed Cheema said that agriculture ensure food security and provide cheap food
to public so that government should not deal it as business. He said agriculture
sector was facing substandard seeds, taxes, value addition and non-subsidised
agri inputs issues. He said China was making huge money by value addition of

political parties did not give importance to agriculture sector in their

it in its manifesto while PML-N has mentioned to grant MFN status to India but

agriculture sector but political parties ignored them again. She said India has
limited land holding size to 12 acres but their agriculture sector was growing.
She said the political parties should announce agriculture reforms in their
manifestos.

Akthar Mayo said industrial sector was given preference on agriculture sector
since after creation of Pakistan which badly hit the latter. He said agriculture
sector subsidy was limited to few people while political parties just make
promises for agriculture sector growth. He said if agriculture sector would be
given attention Punjab could become house of food. He said agriculture sector
save the country of economic restriction after atomic blasts.

                              109 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                      Farm Talk Newspaper (Parsons Kansas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 3, 2010 Wednesday

Ag students have career options

BYLINE: Mary Lou Peter, Farm Talk Newspaper, Parsons, Kan.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1021 words


Feb. 3--Remember when the word "green" only described a color and terms like
"biofuels" and "urban agriculture" needed an explanation?

Plenty has changed over the years, and educating students for careers in
agriculture has changed right along with global agriculture, said Don Boggs,
Kansas State UniversityÂ´s associate dean of agriculture.

For many years K-State has trained students to move into production agriculture,
feed and flour mills, greenhouses, agri-businesses and more, Boggs said.

"People are always associating with the production side of agriculture, but they
often forget the input and post-harvest side. Many graduates choose careers in
marketing, value-added processing and the biosciences," he said.

"We need students with strong science and technical backgrounds," Boggs added,
citing the need for students to move into such fields as biotechnology,
molecular genetics, milling and bakery science and agricultural engineering.

Another change, he said, is the increased emphasis on sustainability: "Farmers
have always been good stewards of the land, but thereÂ´s more research now
devoted to ensuring that agricultural practices are environmentally sound."

Students also must learn the global aspects of agriculture. College of
Agriculture faculty and administrators now encourage students to participate in
international programs like never before. With about half of every Kansas wheat
crop exported to other countries and a strong emphasis on international
marketing of other commodities, Boggs said itÂ´s important for students to
understand the global marketplace--and where Kansas and the United States fit
in.

Agriculture students have opportunities to study abroad, either for a semester
or two or through shorter faculty-led study trips. In the past five years,
students have studied in France, Czech Republic, Netherlands, Costa Rica,
Germany, Australia, Mexico, China, South America and New Zealand.

In addition, K-StateÂ´s College of Agriculture has worked to build a more
diverse student population through outreach programs, some of which go directly
into urban centers. The idea is to explain to students who have no background in
agriculture, that there are opportunities not only in production agriculture but
also in such areas as food product development, biofuels, food safety and other
fields.

Recent university data show that less than one-third of the more than 2,000
students in K-StateÂ´s College of Agriculture have lived on a farm and 50
percent of this yearÂ´s incoming class is comprised of women. And Johnson
County, a suburban county in the Kansas City metropolitan area, represents the
College of AgricultureÂ´s largest single county enrollment.

Emily Surdez, a junior from Sabetha, Kan. is one of those students who did not
grow up on a farm. The agriculture communications and journalism major hopes to
become a book editor and possibly a motivational speaker upon graduation. She
has taken advantage of both an internship within the College of Agriculture and
studied in the Czech Republic through a K-State program.

"Two summers ago I had an internship with the College of Ag Academic Programs
office," Surdez said. "This allowed me to help with orientation and enrollment.
I was able to learn more about the wide array of students that make up the
College of Agriculture. It was neat to learn about their backgrounds and know
that people from any background have the ability to work and serve in the
agricultural industry."

The college has an Office for Diversity Programs and a student chapter of
Minorities in Agriculture, Natural Resources and Related Sciences, also referred
to as MANRRS. Just under eight percent of the agriculture student body is
ethnically diverse. Programs such as the MAPS Summer Bridge Program, Kauffman
Program and Cargill Project Impact are ways in which high school students can
learn about college life and majors in agriculture.

"Through the Kauffman and Cargill programs, weÂ´ve brought hundreds of students
to K-State to learn about being a college student and majoring in the College of
Agriculture," Boggs said in describing some of the programs. In addition, many
of the Recreational and Resource Programs attract non-traditional students.
Programs such as Golf Course Management, Landscape Design, Sports Turf
Management, Park Management and Conservation, and Wildlife and Outdoor
Enterprise Management are attracting students to the College of Agriculture who
may not have considered being an agriculture major a few years ago.

He said that even in the current economic downturn, employment prospects for
agriculture majors are fairly good. He noted that at the most recent
university-sponsored career fairs held for students, as many agriculture-related
companies participated as had been the case before the economic downturn.
Additionally, nearly all College of Agriculture graduates find employment within
six months of graduation.

A 1998-2008 survey of K-State agriculture graduates indicated which direction
respondentsÂ´ careers took: 21 percent went into positions as scientists or
related specialists; 21 percent as managers or financial specialists; 11 percent
into production agriculture; 11 percent into marketing, merchandising and sales;
seven percent in social service; and seven percent in communication or
education. The remainder went into further training in professional careers
(medical, dental or veterinary school, etc.) or graduate study.

Citing a national study, college officials said there will continue to be a
shortage in the number of university graduates with expertise in an agriculture
field. In addition, one in every five people in the United States is employed in
an agriculture-related job.

To see more of Farm Talk Newspaper or to subscribe, go to
http://www.farmtalknewspaper.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, Farm Talk Newspaper,
Parsons, Kan. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20100203-FA-Ag-students-have-career-options-0203

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: FA

                              110 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            October 28, 2001 Sunday

Ag education hits a Growth Spurt; The focus has evolved in all aspects of the
field

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Pg. d1

LENGTH: 1298 words


When most people think of agriculture, chances are they picture fields of row
crops, barns, animals, pitchforks and bib overalls.

The agriculture of the 21st century hardly fits that quaint stereotype. Farming
and agriculture have evolved well beyond the days of 40 acres and a mule.
Agriculture is a much more technically oriented business than just a generation
before.

It requires a higher level of capital investment and technical expertise. The
agriculture of the 21st century includes not only farmers, but also scientists,
engineers, biologists, geneticists and bankers.

In short, agriculture isn't what it used to be. Agricultural educators say it is
much more.

"Agriculture involves so many different disciplines. We can talk about our
industry today in its relationship to science," said Sue Price, director of the
School of Agriculture at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville.

The business side of agriculture also is evolving. Agribusiness has adapted new
approaches to marketing in the past decade with the growth in international
trade and e-commerce.

"Ag education has expanded its focus," said Milt Luckstead, agriculture
instructor at Cascade (Iowa) High School. Luckstead said education at the high
school level includes leadership training and business management.

"We continue to build on our basics and add technology to our programs,"
Luckstead said. "At Cascade, we utilize classroom, ag mechanics lab, greenhouse
and (field) test plots to aid in instructing students."

Price agrees staying on the cutting edge of education at the high school level
is important.

"Agricultural education is one of the majors that reminds us most often of the
changes in agriculture," she said.

In training future agriculture teachers, the UW-P's School of Agriculture works
with high school instructors "who are responding to the evolution and the
changes that are taking place in our industry," Price said.

Production agriculture is adapting high-tech to the age-old profession of
farming. Modern farm equipment is computerized and linked to the global
positioning system via orbiting satellites.

Dave Ahmdahl teaches Northeast Iowa Community College students to work on
complex modern equipment. Besides wrenches and screwdrivers, today's technicians
use computerized diagnostic equipment on farm machinery that is increasingly
becoming more sophisticated.

For example, one new model John Deere tractor has 11 on-board computers.

"This is what our graduates have got to understand and train on," he said. "We
have to continuously add things and bring new concepts" to the classroom.

At the University of Wisconsin-Platteville's Pioneer Prairie Farm, students
learn the applied science side of agriculture. Students receive instruction on
agribusiness, horticulture, soils, crops, animal science and agricultural
education in the classroom and at the farm.

Students can see firsthand the results of new animal drugs and other research.

For the small percentage of young people entering production agriculture,
education is just as vital.

"If they're going to make it they need to think non-traditionally," said Alicia
Prill-Adams, assistant director of Pioneer Prairie Farm.

Agricultural educators agree even in these uncertain economic times, prospects
for graduates look bright. Agriculture graduates bring specialized knowledge and
skills to a variety of professions. A recent survey of UW-P graduates showed
more than half of students who worked as interns returned for permanent jobs
with those same companies.

Ahmdahl agrees the "soft" economy has had a limited effect on the agriculture
job market.

"I think it has to some extent, although the market is great," Ahmdahl said. "I
don't think I've ever had a student who wanted a job that didn't get one. I
don't think there's a shop up here in northeast Iowa that doesn't have at least
one of our graduates."

Ahmdahl has not seen a slowdown in the job market so far.

"We always need more students and the jobs are there." he said.

According to figures compiled by the Food and Agriculture Education Information
System, entry-level salaries for graduates with a general baccalaureate degree
in agriculture averaged $$ @26,748 in 1998-99. Graduates entering the natural
resources field averaged $$ @25,162, while those entering the agricultural
engineering field commanded some of the highest salaries, averaging $$ @34,233.

"A lot of it depends too on how willing they are to move," said Jodie McDermott,
with the School of Agriculture's placement office. The average starting salary
for UW-P graduates is $$ @30,000.

Animal science major Lynnea Courtney, of Dubuque, is optimistic the agricultural
economy will have room for her when she graduates.

"I think it's going to pick up," she said. "I think the job market's going to be
good."

Courtney's optimism may be well founded.

McDermott saw no slowdown in hiring evident for the May 2001 graduating class.

"The jobs are out there if they're willing to take them," she said. Placement
rates are "as good if not better" than previous years McDermott said.
Agricultural engineering graduates are especially in demand, she said.

"Ag education is another one that has really opened up because of a lot of
retirements," she said. Career opportunities in the environmental field -
reclamation and conservation - are expected to grow, she said.

Modern agriculture requires the talents of a diverse cross-section of society,
say educators. Price said it will be important to attract a new crop of students
from all walks of life. Agriculture needs students from farm backgrounds, but
also needs students from rural non-farm and urban backgrounds, she said.

Unfortunately, agriculture is often inaccurately associated with high-labor,
limited skills, positions. Potential agriculture students often do not realize
agriculture is a broad field of study, Price said.

Part of that misperception is because of the rapid evolution of agriculture.
Price suggests it may be time to redefine "agriculture."

Agriculture - the production of food, fiber and renewable resources - actually
employs many professions. To make agriculture attractive to a broad spectrum of
students, Price suggests is may be time to "define agriculture in its broadest
and clearest terms."

"We've got to explain to them the opportunities," she said.

<p>

More women join ag studies

Technology is not the only thing changing within the industry. Agriculture is
also no longer just a man's world.

"It's fairly evident that the percentage of women going into agriculture is
increasing," according to Alicia Prill-Adams, academic facilitator for the
University of Wisconsin-Platteville's School of Agriculture and assistant
director of the UW-P Pioneer Prairie Farm.

Prill-Adams believes the business world is generally more accepting of women now
than 20 years ago. As in other industries, more women are entering the business
sector of agriculture.

"More and more women are going into fields other than education," she said.
"We're seeing more women in engineering, we're seeing more women in agriculture
and they're being more competitive in a lot of jobs out there."

Employers' hiring decisions are increasingly based "not necessarily on what
gender the person is, but what that person has to offer," she said. Knowledge
and skills will be the deciding factor rather than gender, Prill-Adams said.

"Every individual brings a different skill set," she said. "Women are pretty
savvy when it comes to their business skills, and I think employers are
realizing that."

Female agriculture students are often choosing careers in animal science,
pharmaceuticals, communications and banking.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: UW-Platteville agriculture student Ryan Weiskircher moves young pigs
into a weaning pen at the UW-P Swine Complex. Ag education takes on many forms
today, and it doesn't always mean working the fields.

                              111 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            January 23, 2017 Monday

Washington: Rep. Allen, Georgia Delegation Applaud Nomination of Sonny Perdue
for Secretary of Agriculture

LENGTH: 839  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Rick Allen has issued the following news release:



 The U.S. House members of the Georgia Congressional Delegation today applauded
President-elect Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George
Ervin "Sonny" Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role.  Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture.  It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "America's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities.  Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will a boon to
agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven conservative leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with
his business background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture.  Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

Groups weave basket for Africa farming data

BYLINE: SARAH OOKO -1

quarter of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and employing a large
number of people across Africa.

                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            April 20, 2013 Saturday

Agriculture sector to be put on modern lines in Balochistan: Tareen

SECTION: Vol. XXXVII No. 109

LENGTH: 380  words


Provincial Secretary for Agriculture, Muhammad Hashim Khan Tareen has stated
that all out efforts would be made to put the agriculture sector on modern lines
in the province, and for the purpose, special attention would special attention
would be given on the research activities.

He was addressing the oath taking ceremony of the newly elected office bearers
of the Balochistan Agriculture Graduates Association (BAGA) here the other day.

The Secretary Agriculture on the occasion said that all available resources
would be mobilized for resolving the problems faced by the agriculture experts,
officers and staff.

He stressed on the officers and employees of the department to pay special
attention on further development of the agriculture sector as well as research
for increasing production of different agriculture products.

However, he assured that all available resources would also be utilized to
facilitate the officers so as to enhance their capacity.

He said that 75 percent population of the province directly or indirectly are
associated with agriculture sector in the province.

The development of agriculture would yield good results and help enhance
agriculture production, he believed.

He said that the country could get foreign exchange by exporting the agriculture
products once we are self sufficient in the same.

This would be a good source of attaining development and prosperity for the
country and its nation, he added.

He said that since agriculture is very important sector so the concerned experts
and staff should perform well and avoid committing negligence and carelessness.

He also asked them to work on the comprehensive and viable projects for
enhancing the agriculture production and introducing more agriculture grains.

Later, the Secretary Agriculture administered oath to the newly elected office
bearers of the BAGA.

Earlier, the newly elected President of the association presented welcome
address. He also informed the Secretary about different problems being faced by
the department.

The ceremony was also attended by the Director General Engineering, Muhammad
Qasim, Director General Water Management, Abdul Wahab, Director General
Research, Muhammad Anwar Sheikh, Principal Government Agriculture College,
Muhammad Aslam and other concerned officials.

LOAD-DATE: April 22, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              115 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  April 16, 1992, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

MISSOURI'S 'AG ALLEY' SPARKS SENATE FLAP

BYLINE: Robert L. Koenig Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 704 words


WASHINGTON - An alley fight has broken out on Capitol Hill over what one senator
calls Missouri's ''agriculture alley.'' The dispute pits Republicans against
Democrats, bureaucrats against legislators - and the Interstate 70 corridor
between St. Louis and Kansas City against 14 blocks along the Mall in
Washington.  The battle lines were drawn at a Senate hearing last week, when
Sen.  Patrick J. Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee,
claimed that the 250-mile-long strip of the Show-Me state between St. Louis and
Kansas City had become ''agriculture alley.'' Leahy said that chunk of Missouri
is so bloated by U.S. Agriculture Department employees that those 3,350 federal
workers ''could line up . . .  about a football field apart. They wouldn't need
telephones - they'd be able to shout messages to each other.'' Nonsense, says
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan, a former Republican congressman from
central Illinois. Most of those Agriculture Department workers are at a national
accounting center in Kansas City and a Farmers Home Administration finance
office in St. Louis, he said.  And Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., said
Wednesday that ''the real 'agriculture alley' runs from the U.S. Capitol to the
Washington Monument.'' He was referring to the 14-block strip south of the Mall
that includes the Agriculture Department's headquarters (8,000 employees) and
the House and Senate agriculture committees.  Bond also suggested that Leahy
turn his attention to his home state of Vermont, where a recent report showed
that the overhead costs of operating a key farm program is 16 cents per dollar
of benefits - compared with Missouri's cost of 3 cents per dollar. The ''
agriculture alley'' dispute arose at a hearing on ways to cut waste and
duplication at the Agriculture Department, which has more than 125,000 employees
and an annual budget of $61 billion.  ''If the Agriculture Department were a
bank, its $140 billion in assets would make it the second-largest in the country
- behind Citibank,'' Leahy said. ''It's time for USDA to go on a diet.'' The
agriculture corridor in Missouri is ''ripe for consolidation'' because - in
addition to the 3,350 Agriculture Department employees - 48 farm service
agencies and three major Agriculture Department financial management centers are
in those 18 counties, Leahy said.  Madigan said singling out Missouri was
misleading, because about 3,000 of the federal employees work at the Agriculture
Department's national accounting center in Kansas City. An additional 500 work
at the Farmers Home Administration finance office in St. Louis - ''which
accounts for most of the people in 'agriculture alley,' '' he said.  But the
numbers do not add up - especially when you consider that the finance office in
St. Louis has 900 employees. In fact, one source close to the Senate Agriculture
Committee said Leahy's figures on Missouri ''are low-ball numbers. The real
number of employees in Missouri's 'ag alley' is closer to 4,000.'' Roger D.
Runningen, Madigan's chief spokesman in Washington, said Wednesday that ''We
haven't added up the exact number'' of Agriculture Department workers in the
Missouri counties cited by Leahy. ''We don't regard that area as an 'agriculture
alley' - any more than other parts of the country,'' Runningen said.  The
Agriculture Department employs 13,000 people in the Washington area alone -
about 8,000 of those at the department's headquarters.  Besides Missouri, Leahy
said, other areas around the country with high concentrations of Agriculture
Department workers include: Clark County, Nevada, the area surrounding Las Vegas
where 13 employees of Agriculture Department agencies aid 40 farmers.  ''Maybe
the bright lights in Las Vegas make it hard to see all those forms,'' Leahy
quipped.  A 135-mile-long strip along the South Carolina seaboard, where the
Agriculture Department has 314 farm-agency workers in 38 offices for only 4,100
farms.  (Following text ran in the I3* Edition only) Leahy said fewer than half
of those farms (1,063) were eligible for federal farm payments. ''On average,
there is one USDA employee for every five farms eligible for federal payments,''
Leahy said.

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Photo; Photo Headshot (COLOR) ... (Edward R.) Madigan Photo ... Sen.
Patrick J.  Leahy ... Agriculture Committee head Photo ... Edward R. Madigan ...
Secretary of agriculture (NOTE: Photo ran in 3* edition)

                  Copyright 1992 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              116 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            January 23, 2017 Monday

Washington: Georgia Delegation Applauds Trump Nomination of Former Georgia
Governor Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture

LENGTH: 837  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Doug Collins has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. House members from the Georgia congressional delegation today applauded
President-elect Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George
Ervin "Sonny" Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role. Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture. It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "American's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities. Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will be a boon
to agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with his business
background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture. Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: January 24, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2017 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                            January 23, 2017 Monday

Washington: Georgia House Reps Applaud Nomination of Former Georgia Governor
Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture

LENGTH: 836  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Rob Woodall has issued the following news release:




 Today, members of the U.S. House Georgia Delegation applauded President-elect
Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George Ervin "Sonny"
Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role.  Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture.  It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "America's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities.  Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will a boon to
agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven conservative leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with
his business background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture.  Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Rob Woodall has issued the following news release:




 Today, members of the U.S. House Georgia Delegation applauded President-elect
Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George Ervin "Sonny"
Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role.  Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture.  It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "America's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities.  Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will a boon to
agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven conservative leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with
his business background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture.  Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

Washington: Georgia Delegation Applauds Trump Nomination of Former Georgia
Governor Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture

LENGTH: 841  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Earl L Buddy has issued the following news
release:



  The U.S. House members of the Georgia Congressional Delegation today applauded
President-elect Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George
Ervin "Sonny" Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role.  Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture.  It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "America's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities.  Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will a boon to
agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven conservative leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with
his business background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture.  Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

Washington: Georgia Delegation Applauds Trump Nomination of Former Georgia
Governor Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture

LENGTH: 837  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the MP Doug Collins has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. House members from the Georgia congressional delegation today applauded
President-elect Donald J. Trump's nomination of former Georgia Governor George
Ervin "Sonny" Perdue III to serve as Secretary of the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.





 The following delegation members issued statements on President-elect Trump's
choice of Sonny Perdue for Secretary of Agriculture:



 U.S. Rep. Buddy Carter (GA-01): "Former Governor Sonny Perdue is the perfect
choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. As the top industry in our state,
Georgians know how important agriculture is. As a two-term Governor of Georgia,
Sonny has already proven himself to be a strong leader who will fight to ensure
the agriculture industry is able to accomplish their important work. The hard
work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers is critical to the production of
the safest, most abundant and most affordable food supply in the world and I
look forward to working with former Governor Perdue to ensure Washington doesn't
stand in their way."



 U.S. Rep. Drew Ferguson (GA-03): "Sonny is an excellent choice to be the next
Secretary of Agriculture. His experience as a veterinarian combined with his
executive experience as a two-term governor make him uniquely qualified to lead
the USDA. I have personally had the honor of working alongside Governor Perdue
to create thousands of new jobs in Georgia. Sonny has always been committed to
making sure businesses, and especially agriculture in Georgia, are successful. I
look forward to working with him as the Secretary of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall (GA-07): "Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue's
heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and
commitment to this new role. Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number
one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and
private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of
Agriculture. It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in
moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him."



 U.S. Rep. Austin Scott (GA-08), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture
and Chairman of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and
Credit: "American's will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue,
and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his
service to our country's agriculture communities. Agriculture is Georgia's
leading industry, so we're glad to have someone who understands our state's
agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers,
and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture."



 U.S. Rep. Doug Collins (GA-09): "Sonny Perdue is an outstanding choice for
Secretary of Agriculture. The experience he brings to that role will be a boon
to agricultural communities from coast to coast, including the poultry industry,
which is a key part of Georgia's livelihood."



 U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (GA-10): "Given his executive experience as a two-term
Governor and his background as an agribusiness owner, Sonny Perdue is an
outstanding choice to lead the Department of Agriculture. During his tenure as
Governor, he shaped an agricultural policy that helped usher in a new era of
economic growth. Agriculture remains the top industry in Georgia, and I look
forward to working with Sonny as Secretary of Agriculture to continue supporting
our farming communities."



 U.S. Rep. Barry Loudermilk (GA-11): "It's great to see my friend, former
Governor Sonny Perdue, selected to serve as our next Agriculture Secretary. His
proven leadership on Georgia's agricultural interests teamed with his business
background makes him an excellent choice to lead this department."



 U.S. Rep. Rick Allen (GA-12), Member of the House Committee on Agriculture:
"From the farm he grew up on in Perry, Georgia to his service in the U.S. Air
Force, veterinary and agribusiness career, and later Governor of Georgia, Sonny
Perdue makes an excellent and obvious choice for the next Secretary of
Agriculture. Hailing from a state like Georgia, where agriculture is our number
one industry, I am confident in Sonny's ability to represent the interests of
all American agriculture. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I look
forward to his leadership and working with him to advance the needs of our
farmers and the industry as a whole."



 U.S. Rep. Tom Graves (GA-14): "Governor Perdue is the perfect choice to lead
the Agriculture Department. Between his work as a veterinarian and agribusiness
owner to his eight years as governor, he's walked the fields of Georgia to the
halls of the executive office. He has the right combination of experience, and I
have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

have no doubt that Sonny will serve the American people well."

                              122 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            December 16, 2016 Friday

Washington: USDA Sends National Agricultural Classification Survey Ahead of 2017
Census of Agriculture

LENGTH: 354  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: National Agricultural Statistics Service has issued the following
news release:



 In preparation for the 2017 Census of Agriculture, close to one million
potential farmers and ranchers will receive the National Agricultural
Classification Survey (NACS) this month to help the U.S. Department of
Agriculture identify all active farms and ranches in the United States. The
result of the NACS will determine who receives a census of agriculture
questionnaire next December.





 The census of agriculture, conducted every five years by the USDA's National
Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS), is the only source of uniform,
comprehensive and impartial agricultural data for every county in the nation.
Through the census of agriculture, producers are able to demonstrate the value
and importance of agriculture, and influence decisions that will shape the
future of the industry in this country.



 "NACS plays an integral role in getting a complete count of U.S. agriculture,"
said NASS Census and Survey Division Director Barbara Rater. "We ask everyone
who receives the survey to please respond by January 30, so that we can maintain
an accurate and comprehensive census of agriculture mailing list. This is an
important opportunity. The census of agriculture is the leading source of facts
about American agriculture. Farm organizations, businesses, government
decision-makers, commodity market analysts, news media, researchers and so many
others use census of agriculture data. We are ensuring that every farm and ranch
has a voice."



 The census of agriculture defines a farm as any place, big or small, that
produces and sells, or could sell, $1,000 or more of agriculture products within
a calendar year. NACS is required by law as part of the census of agriculture.
By this same law, all information reported by individuals is protected.



 NASS will begin data collection for the 2017 Census of Agriculture in late
2017. The census of agriculture is Your Voice, Your Future, Your Opportunity.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

Washington: USDA Sends National Agricultural Classification Survey Ahead of 2017
Census of Agriculture

LENGTH: 354  words

                              124 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                            January 30, 2015 Friday

Professional training needed for agriculture graduates: J Kumar

LENGTH: 317 words

DATELINE: Pantnagar


Pantnagar, Jan. 30 -- The GB Pant University of Agriculture and Technology
registrar Dr J Kumar has stressed on the importance of practical and
professional agriculture education for agriculture graduates. Chairing the meet
of a committee of five deans for higher agricultural education, Kumar said that
such education can enable agriculture graduates to undertake industrial
enterprises. The inclusion of some new subjects in agricultural research is
important to facilitate this.

The Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agricultural Sciences and Technology of Jammu
dean, Agriculture, Dr JP Sharma stressed on the need for special focus on
practical education to make agriculture graduates more capable of meeting
professional requirements. The professional capabilities of agriculture
graduates can be improved by focusing on practical methods, education, research
and extension in their education, he said.

University of Agricultural Sciences, Bangalore, dean of Agriculture, Dr H
Shivanna spoke of the need for inclusion of subjects like agriculture history,
nano-technology, sericulture, mushroom cultivation and apiculture (bee-keeping)
in the education of agriculture graduates.

Dr PK Chakravarti of Bidhan Chandra Krishi Vishwavidyalaya, West Bengal, said
that agriculture graduates should be encouraged to undertake professional
agricultural tasks for which they should be educated on works related to
agriculture business.

Manarana Pratap University of Agriculture and Technology, Udaipur, dean of
Agriculture Dr SK Malu stressed on the need to also focus on capacity building
for faculty.

Jawaharlal Nehru Krishi Vishwavidyalaya, Jabalpur, dean of agriculture Dr SK Rao
also expressed his views in the meeting.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: January 29, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              125 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            December 8, 2014 Monday

Duplissie named 2015 Maine Agriculture in the Classroom Teacher of the Year

LENGTH: 705 words

DATELINE: ORONO


- Kevin Duplissie, director and head teacher of the Child Study Center at the
University of Maine, has been named the 2015 Maine Agriculture in the Classroom
Teacher of the Year.


Duplissie, who also teaches psychology courses in cognitive and social
development in children at UMaine, has been working at the university for 27
years and teaching at the Child Study Center for 12 years.


The preschool education center offers a developmentally based curriculum focused
on agriculture, art, language and self-help. The center also serves as a lab for
the UMaine Psychology Department and other academic programs.


Duplissie, who has been using Ag in the Classroom's food, land and people
curriculum since 2008, integrates agriculture into every subject and conducts
several agriculture-related activities with the college students and preschool
children each week.


"I'm from northern Maine," Duplissie said. "I grew up surrounded by agriculture
so it's second nature to me. A lot of preschool and college students don't
understand the importance of agriculture in our lives."


Teaching children about agriculture while they're young is important, Duplissie
said, because at the preschool age, they're learning and retaining information
quickly.


"If they can learn about agriculture now, they can build upon it later," he
said. "If you explain and demonstrate agriculture to children, they're able to
grasp it, understand it and work with it."


Each year, Maine Agriculture in the Classroom recognizes an outstanding
elementary or secondary school teacher who uses agricultural education materials
and-or activities in the classroom.


With Duplissie's guidance, preschool children build greenhouses, plant gardens,
visit farms and hatch chicks every year at the center. Teaching children where
their food comes from is an important focus of the curriculum.


"We make snacks with the children, and they know where it comes from," he said,
adding that the students grew pumpkins and made cookies and muffins with them
during the fall. "We relate it all back to agriculture and the farms that grow
their food. Good nutrition is easy to relate back to agriculture. Everything we
eat comes from farms."


At the center, Duplissie works with college students from several majors,
including marine science, early development and nursing. He said he enjoys
watching the students learn while they teach others.


"I get the chance to work with students who see and use education firsthand," he
said. "The more experience and the more you do things, the more it sticks with
you. We want them to see and follow children's development, and help enhance
it."


Maine Agriculture in the Classroom is a grassroots program coordinated by the
United States Department of Agriculture and housed at the Maine Department of
Agriculture. The primary funding source in Maine is the agriculture specialty
license plate. Programs are designed to help preschool through 12th-grade
students gain a greater awareness of the role of agriculture in their daily
lives so they will become citizens who support wise agricultural policies and
local agriculture endeavors.


Duplissie and his program have received several Maine Agriculture in the
Classroom grants to fund the agriculture curriculum at the Child Study Center.
The program uses lesson plans available through Maine Agriculture in the
Classroom and provides annual field trips to local farms and orchards.


"This recognition shows that our little program is doing some pretty neat
things; even a small program like this can be reaching out. Our projects are
being replicated by other teachers in other parts of the state and they are
expanding something we have created," he said.


Duplissie said even though he's honored to be the 2015 Maine Agriculture in the
Classroom Teacher of the Year, he doesn't teach for recognition.


"I like what I'm doing," he said. "I do it because I enjoy seeing the kids learn
and grow. Those are the things that fuel me to continue on."


As the 2015 MAITC Teacher of the Year, Duplissie will attend the National
Agriculture in the Classroom conference in June 2015 in Louisville, Kentucky,
where he will meet other teachers from around the country and abroad who are
using agriculture to teach their students.

LOAD-DATE: December 9, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2014 Bangor Daily News

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            December 8, 2014 Monday

Duplissie named 2015 Maine Agriculture in the Classroom Teacher of the Year

LENGTH: 705 words

DATELINE: ORONO


- Kevin Duplissie, director and head teacher of the Child Study Center at the
University of Maine, has been named the 2015 Maine Agriculture in the Classroom
Teacher of the Year.

The preschool education center offers a developmentally based curriculum focused

                            Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)

                           September 3, 2013 Tuesday

Hayleys Agriculture dominates Agbiz Awards 2013

LENGTH: 484 words

DATELINE: Sri Lanka


Sri Lanka, Sept. 3 -- Hayleys Agriculture, the agribusiness division of the
Hayleys conglomerate, once again dominated the Agbiz Awards of the National
Agribusiness Council, winning 10 awards including a record five Golds at the
awards ceremony recently at the BMICH.

The chief guest was Agriculture Minister Mahinda Ya p a Abeywardena. Hayleys
Agriculture has been consistently recognized for its outstanding contribution to
agriculture in Sri Lanka and has been in the forefront of the country's
agricultural development.

Managing Director Rizvi Zaheed said, "The awards won by Hayleys is in
recognition of this outstanding contribution and gives the company the impetus
to constantly innovate, transform agriculture in Sri Lanka."

Activities of Hayleys Agriculture cover the entire range from the provision of
high quality inputs for modern and sustainable agriculture to the international
marketing of high quality value-added food and horticultural products. Hayleys
had provided the grassroots level leadership through innovation and best
practices in agriculture that has helped farmers and agribusinesses in Sri Lanka
to achieve improved yields and enhanced incomes. The company is constantly
researching and introducing appropriate and sustainable products and services to
the entire agriculture community and has helped modernize and contribute to the
development of all key areas in the agriculture, dairy and animal health
sectors.

Hayleys Agriculture pioneered the introduction of hybrid flower seeds in Sri
Lanka, developed commercial rain-water harvesting, researched and introduced
high quality seeds and planting materials, provided the leadership for
mechanization of agriculture and is the only company to have successfully taken
a wide a range of value-added agri and food products to important global
markets.

The Food Export division of Hayleys Agriculture accounts for over 47 percent of
Sri Lanka's exports of fruits and vegetables and is the only Sri Lankan company
to have expanded to such a wide range of markets across the world with
innovative and high value food products which has helped to significantly
enhance the image and capability of the country as a producer of such high
quality consumer and B2B products.

The strong involvement of Hayleys Agriculture with the farming community
throughout-grower partnerships, agri extension services and with the country's
government and research agencies has given Hayleys a prominent place in the
agriculture sector. With the aim of further contributing to the development of
Sri Lankan farmer community, Hayleys Agriculture presented the first prize of a
two-wheel tractor to the first prize winner of the Agbiz Farmer Awards.

                               Right Vision News

                           December 5, 2012 Wednesday

Pakistan: CM launches KPK Mechanized Farming Project

LENGTH: 524 words

DATELINE: PESHAWAR


PESHAWAR, Dec. 5 -- Chief Minister Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) Amir Haider Khan
Hoti has formally launched KPK Mechanized Farming Project at Tarnab Farm on
Monday. Hoti said that the project and KPK agriculture policy will prove
harbinger of progress in active government functionaries, financial improvement
of farmers and progress in agriculture production.

He said that the project will make available modern technology, environment and
facilities to enable farmers to yield more production from their limited areas.
The CM said that government's responsibilities in agriculture enhanced sector
due to 18th amendment, agriculture policy congruent to modern needs was needed.
He said that 10 years agriculture policy with assistance of F.A.O, has been
prepared bearing self-sufficiency in agriculture and achievement of priorities
in mind, adding, implementation on the policy has commenced. He said that under
the policy farmers will be provided with modern technology at subsidized rates
and other benefits and facilities. He said that resources will be provided to
Model Farms Services Center in the form of endowment fund. The province has
taken the lead in preparing agriculture policy at national and provincial level
under which guidance will be provided to agriculture sector for coming 10 years.
He said that agriculture has a role of backbone in provincial economy and our
rural development depended 80% on agriculture. He said that the present
government has allocated Rs. 2 billion to agriculture for achieving self
sufficiency in agriculture this year but the previous government has allocated
Rs.322 million. He said that the present government was committed for removal of
darkness of ignorance through light of knowledge, adding, establishment of eight
universities, scholarships for intelligent students, financial assistance to
students of far flung areas through public private partnership, financial
assistance to families for girl's education in Torghar and Kohistan districts
and other programs reflect this commitment of the government. He said that
future of the province was linked to investment in hydel power, oil and gas and
agriculture. He approved construction of road from GT Road to Tarnab Farm and
issued directives to concerned authorities in this connection. The CM
distributed endowment funds cheques among representatives of different farms
services centers and offered honorary certificates to prominent agriculture
scientists and officers and personnel of livestock and agriculture departments.
Secretary Agriculture Department, Muhammad Afsar Khan presented the welcome
address, while project manager F.A.O David Dolan threw detailed light on crux of
agriculture policy. Provincial ministers Arbab Muahammad Ayub Jan and Haji
Hidayat Ullah Khan also addressed the gathering. Earlier the CM launched
mechanized farming project by cutting the ribbon. He inspected modern
agriculture machinery and exhibition Published by HT Syndication with permission
from Right Vision News. For any query with respect to this article or any other
content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              129 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                  Manila Times

                            June 21, 2006 Wednesday

MAGSAYSAY TO GOVT: STUDENTS' INTEREST IN AGRICULTURE, FISHERY COURSES MUST BE
REVIVED

LENGTH: 459 words


SEN. Ramon Magsaysay Jr., chairman of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, said
on Tuesday that the government must focus on boosting growth, opening up
business opportunities and creating more jobs in the agriculture and fisheries
sectors to rekindle Filipino students' interest in agriculture- and
fisheries-related courses.

Magsaysay was reacting to report of the Commission on Higher Education on the
diminishing interest of students in the study of agriculture and fisheries
despite the Philippines being an agriculture country.

CHED said the waning interest in the two courses is evident in the sharp decline
of enrollees from school year 2002 to 2005, which dropped by almost 50 percent.

The commission reported that at least 84,609 students were enrolled in schools
offering agriculture and fisheries courses for school year 2002-03. Enrollment
plummeted to 78,201 for SY 2003-04 and further declined to 70,680 for SY
2004-05.

CHED said that the low-employment rate for agriculture degree-holders discourage
Filipino students from enrolling in these two programs.

Magsaysay urged the government to address the problem by generating more jobs in
the agriculture and fisheries sectors and providing more scholarships and
incentives to students willing to purse agriculture and fisheries-related
courses.

Reacting on CHED's statement that it might also stop giving board examinations
for agriculture and fisheries graduates since this could have contributed to the
students' declining interest, Magsaysay said that the Agriculture and Fisheries
Modernization Act requires agriculture and fisheries graduates to take the
licensure examination. "CHED, therefore, could not just stop it without amending
the act," he said.

Magsaysay said that those who have not passed the licensure examination should
not be discouraged because they could also be given eligibility.

"Under the AFMA, those who have not passed the Civil Service Examination for
fisheries and agriculture but have served the industry in private or public
capacity for not less than five years shall be automatically granted eligibility
by the Board of Examiners," he said.

Magsaysay said that the Congressional Oversight Committee on Agriculture and
Fisheries Modernization, in coordination with the National Food and Agriculture
Council and other government institutions, has also initiated the Young Farmers'
Program to encourage young agriculture graduates and those who have not passed
the board examination, to engage in agribusiness.

"With this program, we can expect that more small and medium enterprises will be
established and more jobs would be generated especially in the countryside. This
could also minimize the migration of rural workers to the metropolis and foreign
lands," he said.

LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Regulation/Government Policy

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
